{| style="float:right; background:transparent;" <!--Table to prevent [edit] links becoming bunched (cf [[WP:BUNCH]])--> |{{Infobox F1 driver| name = SÃ©bastien Bourdais | image = Bourdais.jpg | caption = Bourdais during his ChampCar days | nationality = [[France]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|2|28|df=y}} | Years = {{F1|2008}}â{{F1|2009}} | Team(s) = [[Scuderia Toro Rosso]] | Races = 27 | Championships = 0 | Wins = 0 | Podiums = 0 | Points = 6 | Poles = 0 | Fastest laps = 0 | First race = [[2008 Australian Grand Prix]] | First win = | Last win = | Last race = [[2009 German Grand Prix]] | Last season = 2009 | Last position = 19th (2 pts) | }} {{Infobox Le Mans driver | Name = | Image = | Nationality = | Years = [[1999 24 Hours of Le Mans|1999]]â[[2002 24 Hours of Le Mans|2002]], [[2004 24 Hours of Le Mans|2004]], [[2007 24 Hours of Le Mans|2007]], [[2009 24 Hours of Le Mans|2009]]â[[2011 24 Hours of Le Mans|2011]] | Team(s) = [[Larbre CompÃ©tition]], [[Pescarolo Sport]], [[Peugeot Sport]]| Best Finish = 2nd ([[2007 24 Hours of Le Mans|2007]], [[2009 24 Hours of Le Mans|2009]], [[2011 24 Hours of Le Mans|2011]]) | Class Wins = 0 | }} |} '''SÃ©bastien Olivier Bourdais'''<ref>{{cite news| title =Sebastien Bourdais| publisher =news.bbc.co.uk| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/drivers_and_teams/7878995.stm| date =2009-03-02| accessdate =2009-03-05}}</ref> (born February 28, 1979 in [[Le Mans]]) is a [[France|French]] race car driver. He is one of the most successful drivers in the history of the [[Champ Car|Champ Car World Series]], having won four successive championships from [[2004 Champ Car season|2004]] to [[2007 Champ Car season|2007]].
He drove in [[Formula One]] for the [[Toro Rosso]] team during the 2008, and start of 2009 season, but was unable to translate his past successes to that competition. Bourdais currently drives for [[Peugeot Sport]] in the [[Intercontinental Le Mans Cup]] and for [[Dale Coyne Racing]] in the [[IndyCar Series]] competing in all road and street races of the [[2011 IndyCar Series season|2011 season]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.indycar.com/news/show/55-izod-indycar-series/41974-bourdais-returns-to-adopted-hometown/|title=Bourdais returns to adopted hometown|date=25 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sbourdais.com/news/news.php?lang=fr|title=Baltimore â 08/09/11|date=8 September 2011|quote=We were denied a real podium opportunity but there is still an IndyCar race remaining at Motegi. (translated from French).}}</ref>
==Early years== ===Karting=== Born into a racing family (his father Patrick races in touring cars, hill climbs, and sports cars), Bourdais began his racing career at age 10 in [[Kart racing|karts]]. During the early 1990s, he competed in a variety of karting championships, winning the Maine Bretagne League in 1991 and the Cadet France championship in 1993. Bourdais was part of the winning Sologne Karting team which won the 1996 24 hour Le Mans kart race at the Circuit Alain Prost on a Merlin chassis with Atomic motors.
===Junior formulae=== Bourdais progressed to [[Open-wheel racing|single-seater]] racing in 1995, finishing 9th in the [[F4 Eurocup 1.6|Formula Campus]] Championship. He then spent two years in the [[Championnat de France Formula Renault 2.0|French Formula Renault Championship]], ultimately finishing second in points in 1997 after winning four races and five pole positions. In 1998, he won five races to become Rookie of the Year (6th overall) in [[French Formula Three Championship|French F3]]. He won the series outright in 1999, with eight wins and three poles.
===Formula 3000=== Following his success in the lower formulae, Bourdais joined the [[Prost (racing team)|Prost Junior Team]] in the [[International Formula 3000|International F3000]] Championship. He finished ninth in the series with one pole and a best finish of second. In 2001, Bourdais moved to the [[DAMS]] team in Formula 3000 and took his first win in the series at [[Silverstone Circuit|Silverstone]]. He changed teams again for [[2002 International Formula 3000 season|2002]], taking his [[Super Nova Racing]] car to three victories and seven pole positions. He beat [[Giorgio Pantano]] to the championship by two points after [[TomÃ¡Å¡ Enge]], who had scored the most points, was penalised for failing a drug test.<ref name="bourdaisf1fbio">{{cite web | title = Who's Who: Sebastien Bourdais | publisher = F1Fanatic.co.uk | year = 2007 | url = http://www.f1fanatic.co.uk/f1-information/whos-who/whos-who-b/sebastien-bourdais | accessdate =2007-08-11}}</ref>
==Champ Car career== {{Champ Car driver| Name = SÃ©bastien Bourdais | Nationality = {{flagicon|France}} French | Car number = | Team = | Races = 73 | Championships = 4 (2004, 2005, 2006, 2007) | Wins = 31 | Podiums = 44 | Poles = 31 | First race = {{flagicon|USA}} [[2003 Grand Prix of St. Petersburg]] | Last race = {{flagicon|MEX}} [[2007 Gran Premio Tecate|2007 Gran Premio de Mexico]] | First win = {{flagicon|GBR}} [[2003 London Champ Car Trophy|2003 London Champ Car Trophy (Brands Hatch)]] | Latest win = {{flagicon|MEX}} [[2007 Gran Premio Tecate|2007 Gran Premio de Mexico]] | }}
[[Image:Sebastien Bourdais 2005 Long Beach.jpg|thumb|left|Bourdais won his second Champ Car title in 2005.]]
Following in the footsteps of recent F3000 graduates such as [[Juan Pablo Montoya]] and [[Bruno Junqueira]], Bourdais moved to [[Champ Car]] racing in the United States and joined [[Newman-Haas Racing]] for the [[2003 CART season]]. At [[St. Petersburg, Florida]], Bourdais became the first rookie since [[Nigel Mansell]] to claim pole position for his very first race. However, he did not finish higher than 11th until his fourth race, when he led 95 laps en route to his first Champ Car victory at [[Brands Hatch]].
He followed this up with another victory at [[EuroSpeedway Lausitz|Lausitzring]]. By the end of the season, he had earned five more podium finishes, including a win from pole at [[Burke Lakefront Airport|Cleveland]]. With a runner-up finish in Mexico City, he clinched the Rookie of the Year title and finished 4th in the overall standings.
Staying with Newman-Haas for 2004, Bourdais dominated the Champ Car series with seven wins and eight poles in his McDonald's-sponsored [[Lola Cars|Lola]], beating his team mate Junqueira by 28 points. His record also included podium finishes in 10 out of 14 events and qualifying results no lower than third all season.
[[Image:Sebastien Bourdais 2007.jpg|thumb|right|Bourdais winning the [[2007 Grand Prix of Houston]].]]
Bourdais successfully defended his Champ Car title in [[2005 Champ Car season|2005]] with five wins in six races towards the end of the season, again with the Newman-Haas/Lanigan team. That May, he also finished 12th in his first [[2005 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]].
Bourdais won a third consecutive Champ Car title in [[2006 Champ Car season|2006]]. His season began with four consecutive victories at Long Beach, Houston, Monterrey, and Milwaukee, although his winning streak was ended by the emergence of [[A. J. Allmendinger]], who won three races in a row through the middle of the season. Bourdais responded with a commanding victory from pole at San Jose, leaving him leading the Champ Car points standings.
However, an incident with his arch-rival [[Paul Tracy]] that knocked him out on the final lap of the following race in Denver, and a subsequent win by Allmendinger narrowed the gap between the two. Bourdais's win in Montreal and Allmendinger's DNF had widened his points lead to 62 points with three races left, and Bourdais clinched the championship at the next race in Surfers Paradise despite a weak performance in that race. Bourdais became the first Champ Car driver to win three consecutive titles since [[Ted Horn]] achieved the hat trick in 1948.
Bourdais won a fourth consecutive Champ Car title in 2007 with victory at Lexmark Indy 300 on October 21.
==Formula One career== ===Pre-Champ Car=== In 2002, Bourdais got his first F1 test with the [[Arrows]] team and was signed on to drive for the team<ref>[http://www.formula1.com/teams_and_drivers/drivers/834/ The Official Formula 1 Website<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> but the team were on the verge of bankruptcy. In December he tested for [[Renault F1|Renault]] at Jerez but fellow Frenchman [[Franck Montagny]] secured the test drive instead of Bourdais.<ref name="bourdaisf1fbio"/>
===Toro Rosso=== [[Image:Sebastien Bourdais 2008 Japan free practice.jpg|thumb|right|Bourdais driving for Toro Rosso at the [[2008 Japanese Grand Prix]].]] [[File:Bourdais 2009 Malaysian GP 1.jpg|thumb|right|Bourdais driving for Toro Rosso at the [[2009 Malaysian Grand Prix]].]]
Bourdais returned to F1 in 2007 after being given several tests with [[Scuderia Toro Rosso]]. On August 10, 2007 it was announced that Bourdais would race for Toro Rosso in 2008, replacing [[Vitantonio Liuzzi]]<ref>{{cite web | publisher = F1Fanatic.co.uk | title=Bourdais replaces Liuzzi for 2008 | date=2007-08-10 | url=http://www.f1fanatic.co.uk/2007/08/10/bourdais-replaces-liuzzi-for-2008/ | accessdate=2007-08-10}}</ref> and partnering [[Sebastian Vettel]]. On March 16, 2008 Bourdais competed in his first Formula One Championship race, the [[2008 Australian Grand Prix]] in [[Melbourne]]. After qualifying in 17th position he took advantage of mistakes made by other drivers, in the first Formula One race since the [[2001 San Marino Grand Prix]] without traction control, and worked his way up to fourth. However, with three laps remaining an engine problem forced Bourdais to retire, but he was still classified 8th having completed more than 90% of the race distance. He later inherited seventh place (and two Championship points) after the disqualification of [[Rubens Barrichello]].
Bourdais qualified ninth for the [[2008 Belgian Grand Prix|Belgian Grand Prix]]. During the race he quickly gained places and held on to fifth place for much of the distance, and was on course for a podium position. As the rain fell harder on the last lap he was overtaken by several cars on wet tyres and finished 7th. After the race an emotional Bourdais was in tears following the result. This marked his best weekend of the season and his first World Championship points since Melbourne.
Bourdais qualified in fourth place for the [[2008 Italian Grand Prix]]. However, his car would not select first gear on the grid and had to start from the pit lane, a lap down (as the race started behind the safety car, there was no warm-up lap). Although he eventually finished a lap behind the race winner, team-mate Vettel, he set the second fastest lap of the race; only [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari's]] [[Kimi RÃ¤ikkÃ¶nen]] went faster. At the [[2008 Japanese Grand Prix]] he was 6th on the road, but received a 25-second penalty for causing an avoidable accident with [[Felipe Massa]] dropping him to 10th. Few agreed with the decision â [[ITV]]'s [[Martin Brundle]] had stated during live TV coverage of the race that he felt Massa might receive a penalty, whilst his colleague [[James Allen (journalist)|James Allen]] states that 99% of experts he spoke to felt that Bourdais did not deserve a penalty; the FIA were under such public scrutiny at the time following a string of controversial decisions that they made the unprecedented step of releasing publicly "stewards only" footage of the incident, to justify the decision.<ref>[http://www.itv-f1.com/Feature.aspx?Type=James_Allen&id=44254 James Allen's verdict] itv.com F1</ref>
Bourdais tested significantly for the Toro Rosso team during the winter, though he was uncertain of a drive heading in to the new year. On 6 February 2009 however he was confirmed as a Toro Rosso driver for a second year, partnering Swiss rookie [[SÃ©bastien Buemi]].<ref>{{cite news | work = autosport.com | publisher = [[Haymarket Group|Haymarket Publications]] | first = Matt | last = Beer | title = Bourdais confirmed at Toro Rosso | date = 2009-02-06 | url = http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/73147/ | accessdate = 2009-02-06}}</ref> Despite two points finishes in the year at the [[2009 Australian Grand Prix|Australian Grand Prix]] and in [[2009 Monaco Grand Prix|Monaco]], Bourdais struggled to match his more inexperienced team-mate. In [[2009 Spanish Grand Prix|Spain]] Bourdais struck Buemi's car as the field attempted to avoid a spun [[Jarno Trulli]] on the first lap, ending the race for both drivers. At the [[2009 British Grand Prix|British Grand Prix]] Bourdais collided with [[McLaren]] driver [[Heikki Kovalainen]], again ending the race for both. At the [[2009 German Grand Prix|German Grand Prix]] he suffered a mechanical failure after qualifying last by over a second.
On 16 July 2009, Toro Rosso announced that Bourdais would no longer be driving for the team. Toro Rosso's Franz Tost said in a statement that the partnership had not met up to expectations and that Bourdais would be replaced as from the [[2009 Hungarian Grand Prix|Hungarian Grand Prix]].<ref>{{cite news | work = autosport.com | publisher = [[Haymarket Group|Haymarket Publications]] | first = Pablo | last = Elizalde | title = Toro Rosso confirms Bourdais' exit| date = 2009-07-16 | url = http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/76988 | accessdate = 2009-07-16}}</ref> Bourdais was reportedly considering sueing Toro Rosso, claiming that the team had breached its contractual duties towards him,<ref>{{cite news | work = itv-f1.com | publisher = [[ITV]] | first = | last = | title = Toro Rosso confirms Bourdais' exit| date = 2009-07-17 | url = http://www.itv-f1.com/News_Article.aspx?id=46398 | accessdate = 2009-07-17}}</ref> and subsequently Toro Rosso paid a reported $2.1 million to Bourdais in order to avoid legal action.<ref>{{cite news | work = gp.com | title = Toro Rosso settles with Bourdais | date = 2009-08-07 | url = http://www.grandprix.com/ns/ns21710.html | accessdate = 2009-08-07}}</ref>
==24 Hours of Le Mans== Bourdais has frequently contested the famous [[24 Hours of Le Mans|24 hour race]] of his home town, entering for the first time in 1999 (aged only 20) in a Porsche 911 GT2 run by [[Larbre CompÃ©tition]]. The car, which he shared with [[Pierre de Thoisy]] and [[Jean-Pierre Jarier]], retired after 134 laps with engine failure.
He returned in 2000, finishing fourth with [[Emmanuel Clerico]] and [[Olivier Grouillard]] for the [[Pescarolo Sport|Pescarolo team]] behind the three dominant Audis.<ref name="bourdaisf1fbio"/>
His next three appearances did not go so well. He shared a [[Courage CompÃ©tition|Courage]] C60 with [[Jean-Christophe Boullion]] and [[Laurent Redon]] in 2001 but it retired after 271 laps. He drove the same model the next year and finished ninth in the LMP900 class with Bouillon and [[Franck Lagorce]]. He missed the 2003 race and returned in 2004, only for the car he shared with [[Nicolas Minassian]] and [[Emmanuel Collard]] to retire after 282 laps.<ref name="bourdaisf1fbio"/>
Bourdais' next assault on Le Mans would come at the wheel of a factory-backed [[Peugeot 908 HDi FAP]] in [[2007 24 Hours of Le Mans|2007]]. The car he shared with [[StÃ©phane Sarrazin]] and [[Pedro Lamy]] finished the race second behind the winning Audi R10 TDi, despite an embarrassing slide on the first lap in wet conditions that cost Bourdais a place to one of the Audis,<ref name="bourdaisf1fbio"/> and car problems forcing him to park the car for the last minutes of the race, waiting for the lead R10 to cross the line. In his second Le Mans as part of the Peugeot factory team, in 2009, he finished in second place, one lap behind the winning Peugeot. Bourdais was to drive the [[Pole position|pole-winning]] #3 Peugeot in [[2010 24 Hours of Le Mans|2010]], but a suspension failure halted co-driver [[Pedro Lamy]] before Bourdais could turn one lap in the race<ref name="Audi claim victory as Peugeot crumble">{{cite web|title=Audi claim victory as Peugeot crumble|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/84447|publisher=[[Autosport]].com|accessdate=2010-06-13|date=2010-06-13}}</ref>
==Superleague Formula== After leaving Formula One, Bourdais signed up to drive the [[Sevilla FC (Superleague Formula team)|Sevilla FC]] car in the [[Superleague Formula]] series.<ref name="Bourdais to compete in Superleague">{{cite web | title = Bourdais to compete in Superleague| publisher = Auto Trader | year = 2009 | url = http://www.autotrader.co.uk/f1/story/0,25552,14254_5531569,00.html| accessdate =2009-11-27}}</ref><ref name="Bourdais joins Superleague Formula">{{cite web | title = Bourdais joins Superleague Formula| publisher = AOL | year = 2009 | url = http://motorsport.aol.co.uk/motorsport/Superleague-story-83918| accessdate =2009-11-26}}</ref> He won on his debut weekend at the [[2009 Estoril Superleague Formula round|2009 Estoril round]] in the Super Final.<ref name="Bourdais wins on Superleague debut">{{cite web | title = Bourdais wins on Superleague debut| publisher = ITV-F1 | year = 2009 | url = http://www.itv-f1.com/news_article.aspx?id=46803| accessdate =2009-11-26}}</ref><ref name="Superleague: Bourdais wins Estoril super final">{{cite web | title = Superleague: Bourdais wins Estoril super final| publisher = Racer| year = 2009 | url = http://www.racer.com/superleague-bourdais-wins-estoril-super-final/article/148266/| accessdate =2009-11-26}}</ref> Bourdais won again at the next round, winning race 1 of the [[2009 Monza Superleague Formula round|2009 Monza round]].<ref name=" Bourdais making his mark in Superleague, wins race one at Monza ">{{cite web | title = Bourdais making his mark in Superleague, wins race one at Monza | publisher = AutoWeek| year = 2009 | url = http://www.autoweek.com/article/20091004/F1/910049993| accessdate =2009-11-26}}</ref> He returned for the 2010 season racing for [[Olympique Lyonnais (Superleague Formula team)|Olympique Lyonnais]].<ref>[http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/82545 Bourdais joins Lyon for 2010]</ref>
==Sports and touring car racing career== While racing in the junior formulae and Champ Cars, Bourdais made several appearances in other championships. He won the [[Spa 24 Hours]] in 2002 with [[Christophe Bouchut]], [[David Terrien]] and [[Vincent Vosse]] in a [[Larbre CompÃ©tition]] [[Chrysler Viper GTS-R]]. He also won his class at the [[2006 12 Hours of Sebring]] in a [[Panoz Esperante]].<ref name="bourdaisf1fbio"/> In 2005 he also competed in the [[International Race of Champions]], winning his first stock car race at [[Texas Motor Speedway]]. In [[2009 12 Hours of Sebring|2009]], he set the official lap record at [[Sebring International Raceway]], during the [[12 Hours of Sebring]]. In 2010, Bourdais raced with [[Scott Tucker (racing driver)|Scott Tucker]], [[Christophe Bouchut]], [[Emmanuel Collard]] and [[Sascha Maassen]] for Crown Royal in a Level 5 Motorsports prepared Daytona Prototype in the prestigious [[Rolex 24 at Daytona]], held at Daytona International Speedway in Florida. Bourdais recorded incredibly fast laps before the car retired due to an engine failure with Collard at the wheel.
In October 2010, Bourdais drove with [[Jonathon Webb]] in the Mother Racing [[Ford Falcon]] V8 Supercar in the [[2010 Armor All Gold Coast 600|Gold Coast 600]]. In October 2011, Bourdais drove with [[Jamie Whincup]] in the Team Vodafone [[Holden Commodore]] V8 Supercar in the [[2011 Armor All Gold Coast 600|Gold Coast 600]]. Victory in Saturday's opening race and a runner-up finish in the second race landed Bourdais the inaugural Dan Wheldon Memorial Trophy, awarded to the international driver who scored the most points over the Gold Coast weekend. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.motorstv.com/car/touring/v8/24102011/whincup-and-bourdais-star-in-gold-coast-600|title=Whincup and Bourdais star in Gold Coast 600|last=Weeks|first=James|date=24 October 2011|work=motorstv.com|publisher=[[Motors TV]]|accessdate=15 November 2011}}</ref> Wheldon had been set to contest the event but lost his life in the 2011 IndyCar season finale just a week earlier.
